section.name: Introduction
section.p: The Force Field X parent project provides:

ul.li: Shared infrastructure for the development of modules (like this website, mailing lists, forums, code repositories, etc.).
Aggregate documentaion of the source code, API documentation, unit testing and known issues.
A variety of user interfaces that run on all platforms. This includes a GUI, command line version, scripting based on Groovy and even dissemination via Java Webstart.

section.name: GIT the Code
section.p: The Force Field X project is hosted at Kenai with the source code in a GIT repository. " Git is a free and open source, distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency." To clone the Force Field X source using GIT: git clone git://kenai.com/ffx~public-source ffx
In the future, your clone of Force Field X can be updated to the latest version using the command: git pull origin master

section.name: Build FFX
section.p: A Maven project file (pom.xml) is provided to build Force Field X on any platform. After cloing the Force Field X git repository, change directoies into the base project directory. Then execute: mvn deploy This requires Maven v. 3.2 or later to be installed with its bin directory included in your $PATH environment variable. The first time this command is executed, Maven will download build dependencies and Force Field X runtime dependecies. Future executions are quicker. Force Field X will self-test its modules and report failures. Only code that passes all testing should be uploaded to the Kenai repository, so if any test fails it may be due to a local configuration issue. To skip the tests: mvn -DskipTests deploy

Once the build succeeds, Force Field X can be executed using platform dependent start-up scripts located in the bin. On Mac OS X or Linux: bin/ffxc energy examples/alamet.xyz On Windows: bin/ffxc.bat energy examples/alamet.xyz The ffx/bin directory should be appended to your $PATH environment variable. The "energy" command refers to an internal version of the energy.ffx script that can be found in the ffx/scripts directory. To embed your own script within FFX, place it into the scripts directory and rebuild FFX.

section.name: Contribute
section.p: Maven is like "make", but more powerful due to the platform independence of the Jave Runtime Environment. Maven is used to manage the dependencies of Force Field X, compile it, test it, document it and then put everything together into the website.
The Force Field X web site facilitates technology transfer and further development of features. Available documentation includes:

ul.li: Application Programming Interface (API) documentation for Force Field X packages is available as Javadocs.
Force Field X source code is available cross-referenced with line numbers.
The JDepend Report is used to avoid cyclic package dependencies.

section.p: For more information on the layout of the Force Field X project visit the "Project Documentation" area of this website.
